section.heading: Argument of Wade H. McCree, Jr.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We will hear arguments next in Rostker v. Goldberg.
Mr. Solicitor General.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:

This case presents the question whether the Military Selective Service Act by providing for a male-only registration and classification for possible induction into the Armed Services violates the equal protection component of the Fifth Amendment by invidiously discriminating against males.

This is an appeal from the judgment of a three-judge court determining that the male-only registration provision of the Military Selective Service Act offends the Constitution and enjoining proceedings pursuant to that Act.
There is no substantial dispute about the facts giving rise to this controversy.
Since 1948 the Military Selective Service Act has provided for the registration of males between the ages of 18 and 26 and their classification and induction into the Armed Services.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Do all males in that age group have to register?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: All male citizens and all male resident aliens; only aliens not in non-immigrant status.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: But all males including ministers and--

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: All of them register, Mr. Justice Stewart.
The classification system provides for exemptions and deferments.
This condition continued until 1973 when the Congress decided to experiment with an all-volunteer Army and the conscription provision of the statute was removed.
However, the registration and classification provisions continued, as they do today, in effect.

But in 1975 the President decided to discontinue the classification of persons under the Military Selective Service Act and this was the condition until 1980 when the President of the United States sent a message to the Congress indicating his desire because of foreign policy and military exigencies to reactivate the registration procedures and he also requested them to extend the scope of the requirements for registration and classification to include females.
The three-judge case which was--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: --Might I ask, Mr. Solicitor General, is the registration statute explicit as to the permissible uses of the registration lists?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: --It is not.
It doesn't forbid the list for any purposes other than that the stated purposes, but it states the purpose for which it would be used.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Well, what I'm getting at, of course, is, may the registration lists be used, for example, to staff nonmilitary jobs?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: It may--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: What I'm thinking about is during the war, do you recall, when not we, but our allies had all kinds of registration lists which they then used to bring women into war industries.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: --If you're inquiring for service other than within the Armed Services, my understanding is that it does not.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: It does not.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: It's for induction into the military services.
It's not a universal service act, as I understand it.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Except, I suppose, that people who are in certain classifications might be assigned outside the military?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: That was certainly done under the Act and I assume it was done lawfully.

Noncombatant service, within the service, and other service related to the national welfare, I think, was the rubric that was used during World War II, the Korean War, and the Southeast Asian hostilities.

The President requested the Congress to shift funds from the Department of Defense to the inactive Selective Service machinery to reactivate it, to commence the registration of males and females, as he requested, under this message that he sent.

The Congress considered the message and by joint resolution transferred funds from the Department of the Defense to the Selective Service Agency to permit it to function, but denied the request to expand the Selective Service requirement to have women register.

The three-judge case which had been commenced earlier in Philadelphia was then reactivated and the Court determined that by reason of the non-inclusion of women that there was an invidious discrimination against males, that the statute was unconstitutional because it offended the Fifth Amendment and it enjoined further classification.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Solicitor General, you used the term, "reactivated".
When that original action in the three-judge District Court was brought in '71... was it?
was the statute we're now concerned with in the pleadings?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: The statute was still in effect but in 1975 the President discontinued registration under the statute, so the statute still authorized the President by proclamation to reinstitute registration.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: So you have no problem about the action being the proper vehicle for the issues that are not here?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: We do not raise this in our jurisdictional statement.
We don't raise it now.

We believe the matter is properly before the Court and we certainly would rather have the Court adjudicate it now than to wait until a genuine emergency with an injunction preventing the President to act in the best interests of the country.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, General McCree, may I ask, is the statute one that simply authorizes the President by proclamation to require registration or that it directs him?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: It authorizes him by proclamation.
It does--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: And then after this 1980 action in Congress he did issue a proclamation?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: --He did issue a proclamation requiring young men who were born in 1960 and 1961 to register and then on a continuing basis persons who were born after January 1, 1963, on or before the 30 days prior to their 18th birthday.
And that is continuing now under a stay granted by this Court following our appeal from the determination of unconstitutionality.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: General McCree, I might have missed it.
Have these pleadings been amended?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Were they amended in the court below, Mr. Justice?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.
The pleadings were and parties were added because some of the original parties were beyond the registration limit at that time, the 26 age.
Persons were added so that there was an appropriate class of persons who were subject to the requirement of registration.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Is it now aimed at the new statute or the old?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: It is aimed at the old statute because the statute wasn't changed to require the registration of women, and it's still a male-only registration statute.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Marshall
turn.text: Then that's what's before us, is that correct?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: That's what's before the Court at this time, if the Court please.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Mr. Solicitor General... we began interrupting you with our questions and I'm now continuing the interruption... you stated that the three-judge district court held that this statute was constitutionally invalid because it invidiously discriminated against men?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Against men.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: That's clear, is it?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: That's clear.
It was a determination and in fact a challenge was not made that it invidiously discriminated against women.
Other grounds were asserted that the court didn't pass on.
They asserted that it took property without due process of law, that it violated the prohibition against involuntary servitude.
But those contentions were found to be insufficient and only on the invidious discrimination against males was the statute held invalid.

The court below employed what this Court has called in some of its decisions an intermediate level of scrutiny that required that the draft registration be substantially related to an important governmental objective.

And the court below determined that the findings of the Congress on the question of military need did not show an important governmental objective or substantial relation thereto, and made a very extended examination of what it regarded the showing that the Government had made.
We contend essentially two things here.

First we assert that because this case arises in the context of a power expressly granted to the Congress by the Constitution, Article I, Section 8, to raise an army, that the Court should apply the rational relationship standard in determining this validity.
We submit that raising an army and conducting war is sui generis.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Solicitor General, would you take that position if the classification was one that was racially discriminatory, based on the authority to raise?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: I think we would take that.
I think we might do that, but we would say--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: If it was decided, it said, would have registered only negroes and no whites?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: --But we would say that that would not be rationally related to an important governmental objective, because--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: I thought a rational basis test doesn't talk about an important government objective.
Legitimate, doesn't it?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: --A rational relationship to a legitimate... the Court is correct... a legitimate governmental objective.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Burger
turn.text: And you say that would not be legitimate?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: And we would say that would not be a legitimate governmental--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Then gender-based discrimination could be supported as related to a legitimate governmental objective; not racial?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: --We submit that it would and--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: In which case?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: --And not racial.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: How about religious?
Only Jews shall be registered.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: And not religious.
We say that it would not be a legitimate governmental objective.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Only gender base; sex?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: We believe gender base is related to a legitimate governmental relationship for the reason that--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: And you don't have to say that only gender base?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: --No, not only gender base, but we just say the gender base would satisfy it.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: What I'm thinking of, other bases: race, religion.
--We've always talked about--

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Oh, I think I follow the Court's question.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: --We've always talked about something more than the rational basis aspect.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: I would look at the Court's question in this way.
Historically, and in the interpretations by this Court, race is no longer an appropriate classification for the disparate treatment of anybody in this country anymore.
And I think, if I can say anything that I believe categorically, that's it.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Because it's always irrational?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: It's always irrational.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: No matter what test you apply, it will always fall.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: It wouldn't pass the first level of scrutiny.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: But we think that this matter should be determined in the first level of scrutiny, as I suggested, because of the sui generis nature of raising an army to prepare for war.
The Congress is full of references to this, and of course, Article I, Section 8, specifically empowers the Congress to raise armies, to wage war and make rules for that in--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: I take it, in what you said earlier about always irrationality in the case of racial discrimination, you're suggesting then Korematsu has been overruled?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: --I would think this Court would decide Korematsu differently today.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Of course, Korematsu was decided at a time when it had not been held that the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment incorporated the standards of equal protection.
That was first held in Bolling v. Sharpe, if I'm not mistaken.
And Korematsu antedated that decision.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Well, Korematsu certainly did.
Hirabayashi, was that the other--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: That was the other one.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: --The other one, that was decided with it.
And I would say that even viewing the equal protection component of the Fifth Amendment as the Court would now, as applying, it would decide Korematsu differently.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, there's a certain truth to the saying that civil liberties get their greatest protection after the war is over, isn't there?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: I think that's... I agree.
I can't argue with that.
I certainly can't quarrel with that assertion.

But we think that the fact that the Congress has told the... the Constitution tells the Congress, you raise the armies, you make rules for their governance, vest in them an authority that tells the courts that this is something that you should approach with great deference to the congressional primacy in this area.
There are many other areas in the Constitution, as the Court is well aware, that point up this special circumstance.
The writ of habeas corpus, for example, can be suspended in time of invasion.

And the 9th Circuit did uphold a suspension of the writ of habeas corpus in World War II, although there had not been a physical invasion of the Hawaiian Islands; this court denied certiorari in this case.

But it's some evidence of what the Constitution intended the relationship of the Court and the Congress and the Executive Branch to be in this extraordinary circumstance of waging war or preparing to wage war.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, is there anything in Article I, Section 8, that limits the power of Congress to raise and maintain armies just in time of war?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: No, there is no limitation.
It's an authorization just to raise and maintain armies and naval forces.
It doesn't restrict it to time of war at all, and it tells, as we respectfully submit, it tells the courts that this is a matter where great deference should be paid to congressional determination.
And the Congress determined in this case that in the event of a mobilization what would be necessary would be raising an effective army expeditiously.
And to do this it would require flexibility.
And the flexibility that it would be afforded as the record clearly establishes is to have persons who could perform combatant as well as noncombatant roles in the Armed Services.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Well, Mr. Solicitor General, there wasn't any evidence, or was there... was there any evidence before the Congress that registration of women would negatively affect the military capacity?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, if the Court pleases.

There is evidence before the Court that although women can perform and have performed and still do perform effectively and with great credit in noncombatant roles that they are not eligible by statute and policy for certain roles in actual close combat and that it is--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Well, does that add up to evidence that registration of women who surely are being used and could be used in other capacities than combat, does that add up to any evidence that the registration of women in and of itself would negatively affect it.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: --I think it does, because at this time, at the time of mobilization, what would be necessary would be persons who could be rotated among all of the military roles that might be required, and although women could perform and do perform and have performed efficiently in the noncombatant roles, they couldn't be rotated, and flexibility is what is needed, initially, at the time of mobilization.

There is evidence that through volunteer activity it is anticipated that a sufficient number of women would be available in the event of the mobilization that was projected by the Armed Services witnesses who testified here--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: General McCree, am I right in my assumption that no one challenges the statutory provision that women shall not be sent into combat?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: --No one challenges it in this litigation.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Supposing... I suppose you could concede that this was an unwise statute that Congress made the wrong decision in the circumstance but that doesn't make it unconstitutional, is that?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: I would certainly assert that.
I think if we defer to the Congress it really means that we defer to the right to be wrong.
If we just defer to them when we're right, it's not much of... it's not really deferring.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Getting back to this other point about combat, assuming that women are now on the training list for astronauts, couldn't they drive an airplane?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I don't think there's any--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: In combat?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: --I don't think there's any question about that, but the Congress, by statute, has provided that women are not eligible to perform certain functions and the Army has policies that they shall not, too.
Now, the fact that a person can pilot an airplane and even function as crew--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: And we know some men who cannot.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: --And some men who cannot.
The Congress can make this kind of determination if it's something that's peculiarly committed to them and the military people will do it too.
The problem really--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Mr. Solicitor, how did Congress make that decision?
Currently?
Perhaps they did when they passed the law originally?
They refused to change it?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: --The Congress refused to change it--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Which would have taken legislation?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: --Which would have taken legislation.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, was there a proposal that failed to come out of committee or was voted down on the floor or what?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: There were proposals in both houses and on pages 29 through 31 of the Government's brief we set forth in the margin the committee action where this was considered fully and--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Did it ever get on the floor?
Was it ever voted down, actually?
Was it just a committee failing to report it?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: --I believe it was a committee failing to report it out, but I--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: There are not so-called congressional findings?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: --No, but this was before the Congress, and the Congress did enact a joint resolution shifting funds--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: --which means that they considered this, funds--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes, they shifted funds for the registration of males.
But there's nothing in that resolution which indicates what Congress thought about these factors.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. McCree, Solicitor General, may I call your attention to the fact that the conference report explicitly approved the findings by the Senate Armed Services Committee, on page 100 of the conference report on the Defense Department Authorization Act.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: --I appreciate that reference and I would suggest, too, that Senate Report No. 96-826 on page 159 also adopts the committee report and makes--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: The conference report was adopted by both houses?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: --By both houses.
And it makes this specific finding that there was no established military need to include women in the Selective Service System.

Now, we don't contend, in further response to Mr. Justice Marshall, that women cannot perform a wide variety of roles, but the military has made this determination and the Congress has made this determination and it would be against the law to employ them in certain kinds of military activity at this time.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Solicitor General, is it not true that your entire argument assumes that that decision is a constitutional decision, to keep women out of combat?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Assumes... you mean, assumes the validity of the statute--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: --that excludes them from this purpose?

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: It does, but that's not under attack.
No one has attacked this statute.
No one has attacked these policies.
And we submit further that it's... we should defer, the Court should defer to the determination of the military in a matter as vital as this at this time.
Now, it may be that they'll expand the Selective Service at another time when it appears that it would be militarily sound to do this.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, did the military testify against the registration of women?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: The military initially supported the registration of women--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes, registration?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: --but at the same time testified that they would not be inducted--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, yes, but the--

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: --for the purpose of mobilization.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: --But the question is registration, here, isn't it?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Justice White, the question is registration but registration can't be divorced from classification and induction, because they are registered to be eligible--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, the people who testified must have thought they could be separated, because they testified in favor of registration.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: --But they also testified against induction.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So they can be separated?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Well, they can, for the purposes of symbolism.
But people are registered in order to establish an eligible pool of persons who can be inducted.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Do we judge this case on the basis that registration means mobilization of women, or that it just means registration?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: I just think the Court cannot divorce from its consideration of registration the purpose for which it's done.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Well, I know, but Mr. Solicitor General--

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: It is an arbitrary act to register--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: --The same committee report, if I recall it, of the Armed Services, in any event, also made a finding, didn't it, that there were, grave shortages also exist for Army surgeons and nurses?
And might not induction be limited to registrants, women registrants for jobs like that?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: --Yes, if the Court please.

But their needs at this time for mobilization are for persons who would afford them the maximum flexibility, who even, put in the nursing situation, initially, could be used for combat, close combat situation, if required.
And they anticipated--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: How much of that was done in Vietnam?
What percentage of... do you have any statistic of what the percentage was of those who went to Vietnam ever actually saw combat?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: --I can't testify about Vietnam.
I know something about World War II, and I know that the attrition was always at the front.
You might have, say, 100 percent of your personnel and 90 percent may be support and ten percent is actively engaged, but your turnover is in the ten percent.
And then you have to have the flexibility to move other people in there in times of emergencies.

For example, the Battle of the Bulge at the Ardennes, where cooks, bakers, everybody who could carry a rifle was pressed into service, those are roles forbidden today by statute and policy to women, for women to perform, and the testimony here is that the initial needs at mobilization would be for persons who could be rotated into any situation where there may be a military need and all we are arguing here is that the all-male registration at this time be granted.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Didn't the Director of Selective Service testify here that if we had to mount an effort in Europe we'd need 650,000 males and 80,000 women?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Those are the figures that I recall.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Well, wasn't that in support of the idea that we ought to register women so that we can get that 80,000 even in a period of mobilization?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: He thought the 80,000 women would be furnished by volunteer--

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Didn't Admiral Hayward and General Wilson both testify to that effect?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: --This was their experience in the light of females volunteering for the service.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You said that initially military people testified in favor of, Defense Department representatives testified in favor of registering women.
Did they change their mind, or was that their consistent position?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: The Congress decided against them.
They did not... no, they did not change their mind.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So from a military standpoint there was not only no objection to registering women but they supported it?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Except their testimony has to be understood in the light of their further testimony that even if we registered them that we would not induct them.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I understand, but nevertheless, Congress overruled them?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: And the Congress, to which the Constitution gave the authority to raise an army, decided in the light of the testimony that they would like to register women but they would not induct them, decided not to provide for the registration of women at this time.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: There's nothing unusual about the Congress not agreeing with the Executive Branch on a particular issue, is there?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Not in my experience, Mr. Chief Justice.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Solicitor General, if we don't agree with you that the rationality test is applicable here but some heightened test like Craig v. Boren... your time's running out... what have you to say to that if we disagree with you and say there has to be the heightened scrutiny test?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: We believe that we satisfied Craig v. Boren.
We believe here that this is an important governmental objective to raise an army and we believe that registration is substantially related to it, and registration of men is, in the light of--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: When you say "substantially related", is that because of some finding that women are not needed in the military, or must there be some burden that the registration of women would affirmatively cause some kind of problem?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: --Oh, I don't think there must be a showing that women would cause some kind of problem.
I think we have to show--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, then, would you have to show that under the heightened scrutiny would you at least have to show that women are not needed in the military?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: --I don't even think we'd have to show that women are not needed.

I think we'd have to show that to adopt this policy would create a greater likelihood of achieving the important objective, than the rational level cases that it would be somehow related to achieving that--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Wouldn't an adequate answer to Justice Brennan's question be that you need them in the military but you don't need to register them?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: --I appreciate that suggestion--

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: That was supported... that was supported, I repeat, by the testimony of Admiral Hayward and General Wilson, the Commandant of the Marine Corps that they could get all they needed on volunteer service.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: --Just one other thought, if I may have just one moment.

The Congress may also have determined that to process women registrants at this time, since we're talking about 51 percent of the population, they'd need to allocate twice as many resources just for the registration and classification, and if they're not going to induct at this time--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Isn't that just an argument of administrative convenience?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: --I think it's more than that.
It's an argument of talking about finite resources and how they should be allocated.
I see my time has expired.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Weinberg.

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
I think there are four propositions, none of which is seriously disputed in this case, which place into perspective just what is and what is not at issue in this case.
And I think these are four points of reference of which we ought not lose sight.
First, registering women for the draft does not dictate any number of women who will be drafted nor the roles which they would fill if they were drafted.

Instead, registration of women opens the possibility of drafting women to fill the very positions in which they may now or in the future serve as volunteers if there is not an adequate rate of volunteers for those positions.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: May I interrupt you at this point and ask, is it not possible that your next suit, if you win this one, and if women were not drafted on an equal basis with men, would not the same men who are complaining here today bring suit on that basis?
If not, why?

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: Well, I don't think that that would be the case.
One of the issues that the District Court specifically said was not before it and would in fact be inconsistent with its rationale and the rationale of this suit is--

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Inconsistent in what way?

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: --Inconsistent in that the theory of this suit and the theory of the District Court was that you register people as an inventory.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: You register them equally.

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: Register equally as insurance against an unpredictable future.
We don't know what needs are going to eventuate.
We don't know what the assignment policies are going to be when they do.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: What interest do your clients have in having women registered if there are none of them going to be drafted?
It seems here there's no interest whatsoever in just pure registration.

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: Well, I don't think that that's true, that we can say that none will be drafted.
The important point is, we don't know who will be drafted.
If most--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But you must assume that some of them will be drafted or there's nothing worth fighting about.

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: --It is safe to assume, I think, that over--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Therefore there is a connection between registration and drafting, so your first proposition is wrong.

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: --No, Your Honor, I have to disagree with that.
There is, of course, a connection between registration and drafting.
But what's important is that the connection is not that we draft everyone we register or that we draft randomly--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Do you concede that the Government may draft in unequal numbers, that they could set quotas that 75 percent of the draftees will be male and 25 percent will be female?
Do you concede that?

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: --I would concede, indeed, I would embrace the point that the military needs at the time that mobilization is necessary ought to dictate the proportion in which men or women are drafted.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And do you concede that there are different military needs for men and for women?

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: There may be at a given time.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But today?
They need 650,000 men and 80,000 women.
Is that a legitimate constitutional difference in need?

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: It would support a differential induction.
It would not support a differential registration.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But you would concede that a differential induction would be constitutionally permissible?

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: Yes; based upon military needs.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: Mr. Weinberg, if you continue to prevail in this case, does that mean that every past registration and conscription act of this country is unconstitutional?

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: I don't believe that that would be the case.
Questions of constitutionality and retroactivity would, I think, generally be resolved against the retroactivity of the decision.

In a case like this I would note that both the factual setting and the legal standard have been developing over time and I don't see the kinds of clear signposts to retroactivity that are usually associated with rendering a finding of unconstitutionality to be--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: How about veterans' preference acts?

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: --Pardon?

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: How about veterans' preference acts dating from previous draft acts?

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: I think that the Court decided that in Feeney and noting in Feeney that the result of the veterans' preference winds up disproportionately favoring men was a function of the service, which, incidentally, was a result of the inequality of conscription, among other things.

I don't think that that would require the voiding of any veterans' preference statutes because the fact is still that the people served and earned their veterans' preference as opposed to being registered to serve.
And I think that, again, we come to the question, we can no more say who would have been drafted than we can say who will be drafted.

And it's that, particularly that prospective uncertainty that we don't know today what the military needs will be if and when we ever have to draft, that is really the distinction between registration on the one hand and conscription on the other.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Weinberg, up to now your arguments, at least as I follow it, is that there were better ways to do it than Congress did, there were more logical ways, but, does that make it, the failure to do that, does that make it unconstitutional?

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: Well, we go well beyond saying--

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: You haven't got that far yet?

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: --That's true, Your Honor.
We do go well beyond saying that what Congress did was merely illogical.

It was in fact directly contrary to the ostensible purpose, the declared purpose of the statute and for that reason could even be fairly characterized as not having a rational relationship to a legitimate articulated or obvious governmental interest.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Yet you don't challenge the statute that prohibits the use of women in certain combat positions?

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: With all due respect, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, we deny the existence of such a statute.
With respect to the Army, there is none.
With respect to the Navy, there is no statute barring women from combat, merely from assignment to ships or airplanes with combat missions.
For example, in the Navy, women are eligible for assignment to the Seals, which is the Navy version of the Green Beret Special Forces.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Would a decision in your favor here have any effect on Navy policies?

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: You mean the statute?

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: It would not directly implicate that statute.

I would point out that for now several years both the Air Force and the Navy, which are the only two services subject to such statutes, have been requesting the repeal of such statutes on grounds having absolutely nothing to do with registration or the draft, but merely having to do with their own military management.

So what we're really talking about is, I think, the Army situation where the Army now has the right to decide assignment questions according to its own lights, according to its own perceived needs, and I think this is one of the things which distinguishes particularly Admiral Hayward's testimony, because when he said, we will be able to fill it, he was talking about the Navy and the naval requirement for women is very small because the freedom of assignment in the Navy is very small.
In the Army it's a very different case.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: You don't challenge here the freedom of assignment in the... rather, the limitation of freedom of assignment in the Navy or the Air Force?

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: This case does not raise that.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: And you don't challenge it?

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: No.
It's irrelevant to the decision of this case.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Well, we judge this case on the assumption that that is valid.

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: That is correct.

Indeed, the... one of the most important points that I would hope to make is that the District Court assumed the continuing applicability of all current limitations in all services on numbers and assignments of women, and still found as a fact that all-male registration did not enhance military flexibility or the ability of the nation to respond to the full range of possible futures which might confront us.
More importantly, in fact, it found that the exclusion of women from registration undermined military flexibility and that is a finding of fact which has not been attacked here as clearly erroneous.
And on the record, I submit, could not be attacked as clearly erroneous--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Weinberg, the District Court's analysis, of course, was in the context of the heightened scrutiny test, the Craig v. Boren test, wasn't it?

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Suppose we don't agree that was correct, what have you to say to the Government's argument that in any event what ought to be applied here is the rational basis test, and by any measure that that test is satisfied?

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: Well, the finding of fact that military flexibility is in fact undermined by exclusion does not depend upon what test is used in the analysis.
That's a finding of fact that is based directly on the testimony of the military, and I would only comment here what the testimony of all of the Joint Chiefs was, and that was, we should register--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: What's this go to, the legitimacy of the Government interest?
What?

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: --Pardon?

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: What does it go to?
The legitimacy of the governmental interest?

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
We certainly would concede the legitimacy of the governmental interest in raising an adequate armed force.
That is indeed the statutory purpose.

What it would go to is the rational relationship, or on a heightened scrutiny basis, the substantial and close relationship to that interest, and in fact the finding of facts here as supported by the overwhelming record is that the exclusion of women from registration, which means excluding them from the pool of people to whom we can turn in time of war, in time of emergency, for the skills that we know they do possess and the very skills that we have sought to bring into the Armed Forces by increasing the female volunteer rate and the level or volunteer soldiers, we would exclude ourselves from being able to turn to those and the District Court found, and I submit, correctly, certainly not clearly erroneously, that that objective is undermined by excluding women from the registration pool.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Wouldn't that objective be equally undermined by excluding everybody under 18 and everybody over 26?

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: I think not.
We again have a great body of--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: That includes an awful lot of people with a lot of different and varied experiences.

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: --Yes, it does.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: That the military could well use, I suppose.

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: And under certain circumstances, eligibility for induction continues well past the age of 26.
The important thing is, here we focus on registration.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: You did not attack the constitutional validity of the statute based upon its discrimination in favor of everybody in this country under 18 years of age and everybody in this country over 26 years of age?

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: No, Your Honor, for two reasons I don't think an age discrimination case would have been appropriate.
First, the age discrimination standard is clearly the lowest standard.

And, more importantly, there are a great number of reasons consistent with the statute, particularly the maintenance of a strong economy and to minimize as equitable, fair, disruption of life that would be supported by limiting the exposure and... here again, we're talking of exposure of induction.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: We're only talking about registration.

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: And that's what I'm saying, that--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Because from what you suggest, you might as well register everybody over 26 and get a much larger pool to draw from.
There are a lot of retirees, for example, who can perform noncombatant service very well.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: And a lot of former servicemen are over 26--

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: --And to the extent that they generally have continued service obligations and so are within the reach of the statute.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --That's not necessarily true at all.

When you're mustered out you're generally given the option whether to remain in the reserve or not, and I at least, speaking from my own experience in the Second World War, I opted for just getting out.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: How do you distinguish the policy question involved in fixing the ages and the policy question made at this stage for limited purposes of excluding women?
Aren't they equally policy decisions by Congress, whether wise or unwise?

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: Well, to start with, the policy decision to exclude women which was made in 1948 was not a considered decision at all.
There was a good deal of testimony as to what a suitable age for exposure to service would be.

There was no such consideration of including or excluding women using traditional statutory interpretation methods, the contemporaneous statutory history before the same committees, the same Congress, at the same time, the Women's Armed Service Integration Act, I think was quite fairly characterized by the District Court as having been passed in an atmosphere permeated with chauvinism.
There were... the only testimony--

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Since when is it the function of the courts to inquire into the atmosphere in which the Legislative Branch acts?

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: --Where the atmosphere is shown in specific testimony, in specific statements.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, in a case of our Court, this Court, that... do you suggest that that's a proper criterion?

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: I think that in the Arlington Heights case where the question came up, starting, if it's not clear on its face, we then look for congressional intent, indeed, in this very statute on the amendment that was considered in O'Brien, where you looked to whether there was any evidence of an improper intent.
Now, in that case, of course, you found that there was none.

In the case that's before you today, the clear testimony and the clear statements before Congress in 1948 to the effect that, well, no one would want a Wave officer commanding him, that the men would object to being under the command of women, that women would get married and so never qualify for pensions; the entire atmosphere... and, perhaps atmosphere was the wrong word for the District Court to use.
But the record is clear that there was nothing beyond stereotypical consideration.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Well, Mr. Weinberg, if we disagree with the District Court and with you that there ought to be a heightened scrutiny standard here and agree with the Government that that it should just be the rational basis test, can we affirm the judgment of the District Court?

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: Yes, I believe you can.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: How?

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: Particularly, because the defense for the statute even under the rational relationship test is the military flexibility argument that the Solicitor General has described and because that argument simply does not relate in any rational way to either the facts or the intent of the statute, the function of the statute.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes, but if it's just a rational relationship, I would think if you, unless you disbelieve that you could get as many women as you wanted, or that were needed, on a voluntary basis, it would be quite rational to decide not to go through the entire rigamarole of registration and the drafting of women just to get the ones you could get without any expense whatsoever.

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: Well, in fact, there is no substantial basis in the record for believing that we can with confidence predict that we will be--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Well, is there any basis for our believing that we can't?

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: In the record?

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: In the record.
We have history, to start with, that--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well what record are you talking about?

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: --The record before the trial court and the record before Congress.
There was great overlap between the two.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What if we read the record different than you did and then thought that there was not only ample basis in the record but a finding, and evidence, that you can get the women without registration?
What then, under the rational relationship test?

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: If it could be stated that we can safely predict that there would not arise a situation where volunteers would be inadequate, that would be a different situation, but that's not what we face with registration.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, that isn't what I asked you.
Would that satisfy the rational relationship test?

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: Yes, if we had a guarantee, yes, is really would not be needed; the answer is yes.

And that goes, I think, to the very distinction between registration, which is insurance against failing to have volunteers and providing against the broad range of unpredictable futures which do confront us, and conscription, which is the decision when one of those futures becomes our present, to say, these are what our needs are.
We either have or don't have enough volunteers; we need to draft for certain positions.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Well, Mr. Weinberg, finally, why isn't the rationality test, in light of the clauses of the Constitution we're dealing with, the proper test here?

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: First of all, this Court, although often asked to, has never accepted a military relationship or national defense exception to normal standards of constitutional scrutiny.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: What about Schlesinger v. Ballard?

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: And Parker v. Levy?

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: Parker, like Glines and Huff, and Greer v. Spock, are so-called military enclave cases, and they all go off on Parker v. Levy's language about the military being a separate society unto itself internally requiring for matters of discipline and base morale a separate standard.
This statute--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: And we said there that the constitutional First Amendment overbreadth attack that was available in the nonmilitary context was not available in the military context.

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: --That's within a military enclave.
This is not a military enclave case, this is more like Snepp.
Indeed, I think that's the only situation where this particular Act has been brought into question.
And there the Court required the Government to show that the distinction drawn was strictly justified by a substantial governmental interest in waiting for it.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: What about Ballard?

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: With Schlesinger v. Ballard, there are a number of distinguishing characteristics--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: That was within the military as well.

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: --Pardon?

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: That was within the military.

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: That was most directly within the military.
It was an internal matter to the military where it was promotion geared to the military's express desire for the proper pyramid of promotions.
Frontiero was also internal to the military.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: What was the holding in Frontiero?

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: In Frontiero the holding, I believe, was that the distinction drawn--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: This was in the military?

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: --It was within the military, but because the distinction drawn was based on stereotype, it failed the heightened scrutiny.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Failed heightened scrutiny?

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: Heightened scrutiny.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Not the rational relationship?

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: Definitely not the rational relationship.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: It was not a Court opinion in Frontiero, is that correct?

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: There was a plurality opinion in Frontiero--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Not a Court opinion, so it's difficult to say what it was based on.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What was the fifth vote based on?

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: --The fifth vote was based on... I believe, Your Honor, that the fifth vote was based upon an application of a test that went far beyond rational basis.
It was in effect, I think, a heightened--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Reed v. Reed, wasn't it?

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: --It was Reed; exactly.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Why doesn't Reed apply?

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: It's a heightened scrutiny but--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Well, the test is a test of the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment as--

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: --As it applies to gender, which was a close and substantial relationship.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --Reed v. Reed just says this Court scrutinizes cases that are brought before it.

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: It looks for a substantial relationship, and that, I think, Craig v. Boren says that's what Reed says.
Schlesinger's important, really for the ways in which it differs from this case.

Every case, I think, in this Court that has ever cited Schlesinger, and has purported to follow Schlesinger, has emphasized that Schlesinger was a compensatory ameliatory act, that in fact it was uniquely so, because the very men who brought that action were the precise men who had benefited from the assignment differential, which means access to promotion differential, and so that case really is perhaps the archetype of compensatory--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Like Kahn and Shevin?

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: --Like Kahn and Shevin.
It is usually cited seriatim to Kahn and Shevin.

The other thing is, of course, Schlesinger was an internal military case, and most importantly, as far as I can see, differentiating it between this case, other than the internal military matter, is that the basis of classification was not simply gender.
The explicit basis of classification was gender except where the access to the promotions was equal, at which point there was no differentiation.

This Court emphasized it, I think, at least three times in Schlesinger, that where men and women, for instance, in the Medical Corps or the Legal Corps... several other corps... had equal access to assignments geared to foster promotions, there was no difference in the time permitted to achieve promotion.
And that, I think, is very, very important.
The other thing is that historically Schlesinger was not based, even arguably, on stereotypes.
It was demonstrably based upon a recent congressional reconsideration in 1967, in fact, of precisely what was going on.
They found that there was still a gap in assignability, and there was still a gap, most particularly in how long it was taking men and women to achieve promotions.
And so Congress there did reenact, literally, as opposed to what happened here, major provisions of that entire series of statutes, so there really was congressional consideration there.
That's not the case here.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Weinberg, before you... I see your light was gone on... before you sit down, I'd be interested in hearing what the other three of the four points are that were controlling.

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: Thank you, Your Honor.

I think the only one that didn't come up, actually, in the questioning is that in order to justify male-only registration, the burden of the appellant at trial and to prove that it was accomplished at trial here, was to prove a need to exclude women from registration.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Well, it seems to me... maybe I'm out of step, but it seems to me you have the cart before the horse.
I don't think, I have never understood that it was up to the Government to justify an act of Congress.
I had thought that an act of Congress is presumptively valid, and that it's up to you to show why it's invalid.

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: Except where that act draws some form of discriminatory--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Well, as the Solicitor General has pointed out, Congress here exercised one of its explicit powers under the Constitution and with that you don't agree?
You do agree.

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: --If it was an assignment that--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: And I didn't understand the Solicitor General to suggest, and I hope he didn't suggest, that Congress even in the exercise of an explicit power such as this is not governed by the explicit prohibitions in the Constitution, and one of them is contained in the Fifth Amendment, and that's the one upon which you rely.
And that's really the issue here.
But the statute is presumptively valid, isn't it, like any statute enacted by any legislature?

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: --I think not, as this Court said as recently as--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: There is no question of the power.

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: --There's no question of the power--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: And the question is, is that power limited or prohibited?

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: --I would go one step further, as this Court has repeatedly said, when a legislature, including Congress, enacts a statute based upon gender and the distinction of gender is on the face of the statute, it is based upon gender, it is the burden of those defending the statute to come forth and establish by empirical evidence, in fact--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Well, perhaps... maybe the Court has said that, but I trust I never have because I don't think they're defending a statute, I think you're attacking it.

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: --But, Your Honor, once the attack shows that it was gender-based discrimination, this Court--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But doesn't the burden shift as soon as the Government does... and you've conceded they've done here... show there's a difference in military need based on sex?
You conceded that's permissible.

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: --Your Honor, that would affect registration only if two different statutes were involved, one, a statutory prohibition on women participating in certain close combat activities, and the other, more importantly, a change in the Military Selective Service Act limiting the induction of people to people who will be assigned to those prohibited roles, because otherwise we are conflicting with history and Congress did not mean to conflict with history because we have always, as the testimony of General Tice and all the generals is clear, we have always drafted a very substantial, indeed, often a majority of draftees specifically for the noncombat areas.

And most importantly, the argument of flexibility was specifically refuted by General Abrams and other generals in the testimony because we are saying that there is a certain number of women that the military wants to have, welcomes, thinks is the optimal number for the defense of the country.
You cannot at the one point say that that is the military opinion and at the same time say that if those slots are filled with draftees rather than volunteers, we undermine flexibility.

The testimony of every Defense Department witness and every military witness was that all of those criteria, the reach-back, the flexibility, the rotation, the promotion rotations, the assignment rotation, were all taken fully into account when the military said, please let us register women, and let us decide whether they should be drafted, if and when the time for a draft comes.
General Abrams said that he didn't favor drafting women at the time because he didn't favor drafting men at the time.
They were in an all-volunteer mode, as he said, and that since present needs for both men and women were being met with volunteers, he didn't favor drafting anybody at that time.
Secretary Brown kept saying to Congress, let us register people now; and then, when we see what the need is, we can draft them.
This was what we came within a hair's-breadth of doing in World War II with respect to nurses.
I would only point that the utilization question is contrary to what the Government says.
For example, ministers are required--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I would just ask if the case would be different in constitutional terms if the military had taken the position, we don't like women, we don't want any of them in the Army?
Would it be a different constitutional issue?

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: --It would be a different matter of somehow meeting an evidentiary burden.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Which they might have said in 1948, by the way.

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: They didn't.
As a matter of Fact, General Eisenhower's statement to the Congress in 1948 was, if we ever have another war, we have got to draft women.
And that was based upon their performance even in the more limited numbers and roles that were used in World War II.
I would point out that--

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Weinberg, you have emphasized the testimony and I quite agree with you, if I were in your place I would, of some of the military men.
I think you can find conflicting statements if you read in all.
But what I wanted to ask you is this.

The Armed Services Committee of the United States Senate by a vote of twelve to five reached an entirely different result from the one that you reached, and they heard the testimony, not only this year but they've been hearing it for years.

Now, did the District Court reject specifically a single one of the 11 findings made by the Senate Armed Services Committee that were in turn approved by the conferees of both houses and in turn by both houses of Congress?

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: --Yes, I think the District Court specifically rejected a number of them.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: All eleven?
If so, do we accept the rejection by the District Court that tried a lawsuit that were contrary to the findings of the United States Congress?

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We can read the testimony as well as the district judge could read it.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: And if so what authority justifies us in doing that?

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Perhaps the Kassel opinion handed down this morning.

turn.speaker: donald_l_weinberg
turn.label: Mr. Donald L. Weinberg
turn.text: I have not had the opportunity to read that.
The treatment of what happened in 1980 as congressional action was... the conference report said that there was no need to include women.
It did not find an affirmative need to exclude women: Again, Congress was dealing, I think, with the wrong question in that respect.
More importantly, perhaps, the activity of Congress in 1980 was not a reenactment or reconsideration of this situation.
The appropriations aspect of it, the House Joint Resolution, didn't even mention the word "registration".
It was a transfer of otherwise unobligated funds from the Air Force to Selective Service for the purpose of salaries and expenses.
I think Ex Parte Endo with its requirement for explicit mention of a particular expenditure rationale says that that would not suffice.
Now, with respect to S. 2294, the Authorizations Act, again--

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: I think you're going beyond Justice Powell's question now.
Your time has expired, unless Justice Powell wishes to?
Yes, your time has expired.
The case is submitted, gentlemen.
Thank you very much.
